title: Lesson 9: Diffusion and Concentration Gradients
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding diffusion as a passive transport mechanism, factors affecting diffusion rates, and Fick's Law applications.
learningIntentions: Students can define diffusion as the net movement of particles from high to low concentration.
Students can identify factors that affect the rate of diffusion (temperature, concentration gradient, surface area, thickness, molecular size).
Students can apply Fick's Law to predict diffusion rates in biological contexts.

engagementHook.title: The Invisible Crowd
engagementHook.content: Demonstration: Open a bottle of perfume at the front of the room. 'You can smell it at the back within minutes, but no one pushed the molecules. They moved on their own, from where there were many to where there were few. This is diffusion - the fundamental force that moves oxygen into your cells and carbon dioxide out. But what controls how fast it happens?'

keyConcepts.definition: The net movement of particles from an area of high concentration to an area of low concentration down a concentration gradient. Continues until equilibrium (equal concentration throughout).
The difference in concentration between two areas. Steeper gradient = faster diffusion. No gradient = no net diffusion (equilibrium).
Requires no energy (ATP). Molecules move due to their own kinetic energy.
Rate of diffusion is proportional to: (surface area × concentration difference) ÷ diffusion distance. Larger surface area, steeper gradient, or shorter distance = faster diffusion.
Small, non-polar molecules (O₂, CO₂, steroid hormones) pass directly through the phospholipid bilayer.
Polar or charged molecules (glucose, amino acids, ions) use channel or carrier proteins. Still passive (no ATP) but protein-assisted.

misconceptions.correction: Molecules continue to move, but there's no NET movement - equal numbers move each direction.

misconceptions.misconception: Diffusion is fast over long distances
misconceptions.correction: Diffusion is effective only over short distances (micrometres). Cells are small because diffusion is slow.
It uses proteins but NOT ATP - still passive transport down the gradient.

multipleChoice.question: Which of the following factors will increase the rate of diffusion across a membrane?
multipleChoice.rationale: Larger surface area allows more molecules to cross simultaneously, increasing diffusion rate. Thickness and molecular size DECREASE diffusion rate. Higher temperature increases rate, not lower.

multipleChoice.question: Oxygen can cross the membrane by simple diffusion but glucose requires facilitated diffusion because:
options: Oxygen is non-polar while glucose is polar
Oxygen uses ATP while glucose does not
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Oxygen is non-polar while glucose is polar
multipleChoice.rationale: Simple diffusion works for small non-polar molecules that can pass through the hydrophobic core. Polar molecules like glucose need protein channels/carriers (facilitated diffusion).

multipleChoice.question: According to Fick's Law, if the thickness of a respiratory membrane doubles, the rate of diffusion will:
multipleChoice.rationale: Rate is inversely proportional to thickness. Doubling thickness halves the rate.

shortAnswer.question: Explain why oxygen can cross the membrane by simple diffusion while glucose requires a transport protein. [3 marks]
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Oxygen is small and non-polar (can dissolve in/pass through hydrophobic interior)
1 mark: Glucose is polar/large and cannot cross the hydrophobic core
1 mark: Glucose uses channel/carrier proteins (facilitated diffusion) to cross
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying glucose is too big without mentioning polarity/hydrophobicity.

shortAnswer.question: Describe two structural adaptations of the alveoli that maximise the rate of gas exchange by diffusion. [2 marks]
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Large surface area (many alveoli) increases diffusion rate (Fick's Law)
1 mark: Thin walls (one cell thick/epithelium) reduce diffusion distance
shortAnswer.commonError: Mentioning 'moist surface' or 'good blood supply' without linking to diffusion rate.

definitions: Diffusion: Net movement of particles from high to low concentration down a concentration gradient.
Simple diffusion: Small, non-polar molecules cross the phospholipid bilayer directly.
Facilitated diffusion: Polar/charged molecules use channel or carrier proteins (no ATP).
Fick's Law: Rate ∝ (Surface Area × Concentration Difference) / Thickness.
Factors increasing rate: higher temperature, steeper gradient, larger area, thinner membrane, smaller molecules.
keyPoints: Non-polar = simple diffusion; Polar = facilitated diffusion
Alveoli: large surface area + thin walls = efficient gas exchange

shortAnswer: Oxygen is a small, non-polar molecule that can dissolve in and pass directly through the hydrophobic interior of the phospholipid bilayer by simple diffusion. Glucose, however, is a large, polar molecule that cannot cross the lipid bilayer on its own because the hydrophobic core repels polar substances. Therefore, glucose requires channel proteins or carrier proteins to assist its movement across the membrane in a process called facilitated diffusion.

Two structural adaptations of the alveoli that maximise gas exchange are: (1) They have a very large total surface area due to the large number of alveoli (approximately 300 million in human lungs), which increases the rate of diffusion according to Fick's Law. (2) The alveolar walls and capillary walls are extremely thin (only one cell thick), which minimises the diffusion distance and therefore increases the rate of gas exchange.
